meta.content: This paper proposes a current source-type pulse generator circuit to improve load voltage waveforms by solving the voltage ringing problem of capacitively coupled plasma systems. The voltage source-type pulse power supplies used in the plasma industry have short-circuit currents and voltage ringing problems with capacitively coupled plasma loads. The current source-type pulse generator proposed in this paper can solve these problems. The proposed circuit consists of four detailed circuits: bias current generator, bias current modulator, slope current generator, and slope current modulator. They form two constant currents at the DC link, and output two pulse currents to the load. These output currents contribute to generating the plasma load voltage required by the capacitively coupled plasma process. The proposed circuit is verified by a PLECS simulator and a laboratory-scale hardware system. To check the improvement of the output waveform, a voltage source-type pulse generator and the current source-type pulse generator are tested under the same experimental conditions. The results are represented by load voltage and current waveforms. In addition, the entire system of the current source-type pulse generator is designed and verified by simulation and experimental results. The resulting output waveforms meet the process requirements, and the obtained results demonstrate that the proposed current source-type pulse generator circuit can be suitably used for capacitively coupled plasma loads.

meta.content: Pulse current generator with improved waveform fidelity for high-voltage capacitively coupled plasma systems - Journal of Power Electronics

This paper proposes a current source-type pulse generator circuit to improve load voltage waveforms by solving the voltage ringing problem of capacitively coupled plasma systems. The voltage source-type pulse power supplies used in the plasma industry have short-circuit currents and voltage ringing problems with capacitively coupled plasma loads. The current source-type pulse generator proposed in this paper can solve these problems. The proposed circuit consists of four detailed circuits: bias current generator, bias current modulator, slope current generator, and slope current modulator. They form two constant currents at the DC link, and output two pulse currents to the load. These output currents contribute to generating the plasma load voltage required by the capacitively coupled plasma process. The proposed circuit is verified by a PLECS simulator and a laboratory-scale hardware system. To check the improvement of the output waveform, a voltage source-type pulse generator and the current source-type pulse generator are tested under the same experimental conditions. The results are represented by load voltage and current waveforms. In addition, the entire system of the current source-type pulse generator is designed and verified by simulation and experimental results. The resulting output waveforms meet the process requirements, and the obtained results demonstrate that the proposed current source-type pulse generator circuit can be suitably used for capacitively coupled plasma loads.

div.div: Pulse current generator with improved waveform fidelity for high-voltage capacitively coupled plasma systems

header.h1: Pulse current generator with improved waveform fidelity for high-voltage capacitively coupled plasma systems
header.p:
Journal of Power Electronics
volume
20
,
pages
1316–1327 (
2020
)
Cite this article

li.p:
146
Accesses

1
Citations

div.p: This paper proposes a current source-type pulse generator circuit to improve load voltage waveforms by solving the voltage ringing problem of capacitively coupled plasma systems. The voltage source-type pulse power supplies used in the plasma industry have short-circuit currents and voltage ringing problems with capacitively coupled plasma loads. The current source-type pulse generator proposed in this paper can solve these problems. The proposed circuit consists of four detailed circuits: bias current generator, bias current modulator, slope current generator, and slope current modulator. They form two constant currents at the DC link, and output two pulse currents to the load. These output currents contribute to generating the plasma load voltage required by the capacitively coupled plasma process. The proposed circuit is verified by a PLECS simulator and a laboratory-scale hardware system. To check the improvement of the output waveform, a voltage source-type pulse generator and the current source-type pulse generator are tested under the same experimental conditions. The results are represented by load voltage and current waveforms. In addition, the entire system of the current source-type pulse generator is designed and verified by simulation and experimental results. The resulting output waveforms meet the process requirements, and the obtained results demonstrate that the proposed current source-type pulse generator circuit can be suitably used for capacitively coupled plasma loads.

Recently, power electronics technologies have been introduced into the plasma application industry. Typically, various power converters and control techniques are applied to RF generators and pulse power supply systems using the latest power semiconductor devices [
1
,
2
]. When compared to conventional practices, plasma systems employing power electronic technologies have a number of benefits such as improved efficiency, reduced volume and increased energy density. The pulsed power supplies used in semiconductor etching and deposition processes generally require high-performance power supplies that achieve a voltage of several kV and a current rise/fall time of less than 100 ns [
3
]. In developing such high-performance pulse power supply devices, switching mode power supply devices are more advantageous than the conventional linear amplifier power supply devices when it comes to meeting the severe performance requirements imposed by semiconductor processes [
4
,
5
].

In pulse power supply systems, the pulsed pattern of instantaneous power is transmitted to the load through on/off operation of switches using a constant voltage source or a current source as a power source. Generally, the majority of pulse power supplies are manufactured using a voltage source converter [
6
,
7
,
8
]. The reason for employing a voltage source converter in a pulse power supply is that the majority of the available power semiconductor switches in the market are compatible with the voltage source-type converters. In addition, various circuit topologies and their control methods have been established for voltage source-type converters. Thus, the configuration of a plasma system using a voltage source converter is relatively simpler than that of a system using a current source converter.

In general, plasma loads can be characterized as either an inductively coupled plasma (ICP) system or a capacitively coupled plasma (CCP) system with respect to the electrical behavior of the plasma load. A voltage source-type converter as pulse power supply is a good match for ICP systems due to the generic source connection rule of electrical circuits. However, in case of CCP systems, voltage source-type converters violate the source connection rule and can cause spike current in the plasma load, i.e., short-circuit current between two parallel connected voltage sources. Although voltage source-type converters can be utilized for CCP systems with an additional inductive filter inserted between the voltage source and plasma load of the CCP system, the reliability and additional cost for inductive filters of high-voltage, high-current, and fast dynamic response have become a challenging design issue. In addition, an inductive filter can lead to several side effects such as unwanted resonance with a plasma load (ringing of the output load voltage), degradation of the control bandwidth, attenuation of the output load voltage, and a limited slew rate of the output voltage. In particular, the ringing of the output load voltage results in malfunctions and sudden trips of the plasma process in CCP systems. State-of-the-art solutions for the power converters in CCP systems have mostly been utilizing voltage source-type converters. As a result, the power converter systems for CCP systems suffer from the aforementioned problems. Therefore, for the plasma load of CCP systems, a current source-type converter is a better choice since the cascaded connection of a current source with a voltage source-type load does not intrinsically result in a short-circuit current. Considering this potential advantage of current source-type converters in CCP systems, there has been a lot less attention given to this approach in previous studies.

This paper proposes a novel pulse current generator circuit for a CCP system. The proposed circuit topology provides a load of the CCP type with a reliable pulsed power of 1.6 kV/35 A with a fundamental frequency of 100 kHz. The proposed circuit consists of two parallel connected current source converters to effectively meet the target accuracy of the output voltage and current. Due to the relatively high fundamental frequency and slew rate of the target output voltage, a SiC MOSFET is selected as the main power semiconductor switching device. The overall power supply system is made up of four functional blocks: bias current generator, bias current modulator, slop current generator, and slop current modulator. These four functional blocks make it possible to generate a bi-directional output current with a relatively high accuracy. As mentioned above, since it is designed based on a current source converter, it is possible to solve the short-circuit current problem that occurs in the voltage source converter. In addition, the system has the characteristics of a step-up converter because it has a structure where the current source is a power source and this current is supplied to a capacitive load, which makes it possible to obtain a high voltage output from a power supply having a low voltage. Due to a relatively high output voltage, the series connection of multiple SiC MOSFETs may be necessary for cases where a single device cannot withstand the voltage stress.

This paper aims to obtain an output voltage with an improved waveform fidelity and to the solve short-circuit current problem together with a severe ringing of the output voltage using the proposed converter topology under CCP load conditions. This paper is structured as follows. Section
2
describes a CCP system and its important electrical characteristics from the power supply point of view. In Sect.
3
, state-of-the-arts solutions, i.e., voltage source-type pulse power supplies, are introduced and their generic problems are explained. The proposed circuit topology and its operation are presented in Sect.
4
. Verifying simulation and experimental results are provided in Sect.
5
. Finally, some conclusions are given in Sect.
6
.

This section introduces a typical CCP system like the ones employed in semiconductor production processes. The important electrical aspects of CCP systems, particularly those for the suitable design of power supplies, are also covered in this section. In general, a CCP system can be modeled as a series-connected capacitor and resistor as shown in Fig.
1
.
C
Sheath
represents the capacitive element due to the space of the sheath located between the electrode and the bulk plasma on each side.
R
plasma
stands for the load element of the plasma chamber that determines the output active power of the plasma system. The CCP systems typically employed in semiconductor etching processes are characterized as a highly capacitive impedance. For example, a typical CCP system rated for an apparent power of 100 kVA consumes an average active power below a few kW. Therefore, the actual value of
R
plasma
is quite small when compared to the impedance value of
C
Sheath
. Throughout this paper, for the sake of simplicity, the impact of
R
plasma
on the overall operation of a CCP system is ignored unless otherwise notified.
CCP load and its equivalent circuit

The major engineering issues of a semiconductor process include a high precision and high yield of the process. To produce continuously shrinking nano-scale semiconductors, the utilized power supplies must also meet the high-performance specifications of the plasma semiconductor process. In the CCP systems utilized in the latest semiconductor production processes, the following two electrical aspects have been gaining more attention for the reliable design of power supplies: high potential and accurate control of the electric field applied to the CCP.

The first aspect, the high potential of the electric field inside plasma chamber, is required since the plasma is more easily ignited with a higher electric field and a lower pressure gas. In addition, a high potential can improve the selectivity of the semiconductors through the plasma processes. The selectivity contributes greatly to the micro-processing of the semiconductor. The velocity of the plasma ions has a direct impact on selectivity. Plasma ions move along an electric field and their velocity is proportional to the applied electric field. Therefore, if a high electric field is applied, the selectivity of the plasma process can be further improved. In other words, when the precision of a process is kept constant, the depth of etching grows in proportion to the electric field intensity. Recent 3D structures and layered structure semiconductors require larger etching depths. As a result, a higher potential of the electric field inside a plasma chamber is more advantageous when it comes to coping with the ever-shrinking nano-scale semiconductor etching process. Figure
2
presents target voltage and current waveforms across the CCP system considered in this paper. The latest semiconductor etching systems require a peak voltage amplitude of a few kV with a fundamental frequency of around 100 kHz. The rise/falling and falling times of the pulse voltage are typically required to be less than 100 ns. In Fig.
2
, the effect of the voltage element across
R
plasma
on the overall voltage (
V
load
) is ignored for the sake of simplicity. Thus, assuming the load has the same characteristics as the capacitor, a simple capacitor voltage–current equation is established between the voltage and current of the plasma load.

Typical pulse voltage (top) and current (bottom) waveforms of the capacitively coupled plasma system illustrated in Fig.
1

When pulse current is supplied to the capacitor, the capacitor charges linearly during the current flow and maintains a charged voltage when the current is not flowing. Therefore, to achieve the capacitor load voltage shape shown in Fig.
2
(top), the pulsed current shown in Fig.
2
(bottom) is required.

The other important electrical aspect of a CCP system that is applied in the semiconductor production processes is the accurate control of the electric field applied to the CCP. The ever-shrinking nano-scale semiconductor etching processes demand highly reliable and accurate operation of a plasma chamber. Intrinsic disturbances within the plasma chamber and degradation of plasma voltage due to parasitic elements can lead to unreliable operation of the CCP system. In order to avoid this problem, the applied electric field needs to be controlled in a very precise manner. In other words, the amplitude of the applied output voltage (
V
load
) in Fig.
2
should be regulated within a fairly tight range. Therefore, the power supply should be equipped with topological and control features to achieve this accurate control requirement. Figure
3
shows target voltage and current waveforms for a plasma etching system suitable to achieve the accurate control requirement. To compensate for the unwanted charging or discharging of capacitor voltage due to secondary parasitic circuit elements within the plasma chamber, the amplitude of the output voltage needs to be fine-tuned by supplying additional charging or discharging current through the CCP system. This is an effective solution under the condition that the amplitude and duration of the main pulse current in Fig.
2
are fixed and relatively difficult to vary. In Fig.
3
, the amplitude and duration of the main pulse current (
I
dc_bias
) supports the main bias voltage of the plasma chamber (
V
load_bias
). Additional charging current of
I
dc_slope
, whose amplitude is relatively flexible to variations determines
V
load_slope
. As a result, the additional potential of
V
load_slope
compensates for the unwanted charging or discharging of main bias voltage (
V
load_bias
). Thus, the overall output voltage of
V
load_pp
is maintained in a tight range. In this paper, the proposed power supply solution of a CCP system is equipped with suitable topological and control features that can generate the target waveforms of Fig.
3
.

Target voltage (top) and current (bottom) waveforms of the plasma etching process illustrated in Fig.
1

div.h3: Topologies of voltage source-type pulse power supplies
div.p:
Various voltage source-type converter topologies employed in pulse power supplies, including plasma application systems, are described in this section. Pulse power supplies are generally classified by the peak magnitude, duration, and polarity of the output pulse. Figure
4
shows a Marx generator circuit. These circuits are generally utilized for pulse power supplies of high-voltage and short-pulse duration. Under the switching off condition of all the switches, the capacitors are connected in parallel and charged to the same potential as the input dc voltage. By triggering all the switches at the same instant, the capacitors become series connected to the output port. Then, the series-connected capacitors provide a relatively high voltage potential for the output. In general, this discharging of high voltage to the output lasts a short duration. Therefore, the Marx generator is characterized as a long charging and short discharging mode of operation [
9
].
Circuit diagram of a Marx generator

Figures
5
and
6
illustrate Modular Multi-level Converter (MMC) topologies applied in pulse power supply systems. A half-bridge cell is used in Fig.
5
, while a full-bridge cell is employed in Fig.
6
. In both topologies, the switch operation is performed to connect dc power sources in series or to bypass the dc power sources. The size of the output voltage can be adjusted by the number of series-connected switches. Therefore, it is possible to produce various output voltage waveforms such as pulse waveforms, step increasing waveforms, etc. In addition, unlike the Max generator, it uses independent dc power sources that can maintain the pulse output for a longer time.
Circuit diagram of a half-bridge modular multi-level converter
Circuit diagram of a full-bridge modular multi-level converter

However, since a large number of isolated dc power sources are required, the cost of the hardware is high. The half-bridge MMC shown in Fig.
5
can only generate output voltage with a unidirectional polarity, which is a serious limitation for applications requiring a bi-polar pulse voltage [
10
]. On the other hand, the full-bridge MMC shown in Fig.
6
can provide a pulse output voltage with a bidirectional polarity. Basically, using isolated DC power is the same as in half-bridge MMCs. However, a full-bridge MMC uses two additional switches for each module to change the polarity of the output voltage. Depending on the operation of the switches in a full-bridge cell, negative dc voltage, positive dc voltage, or bypass output can be generated. Therefore, a full-bridge MMC has a better flexibility since the waveform shape, polarity, and pulse duration of the output voltage can be widely controlled [
11
].
div.h3: Limitations of voltage source-type pulse power supplies
div.p:
Three different kinds of voltage source-type circuit topologies are shown in Fig.
4
through Fig.
6
. These topologies are widely used in various pulse power supplies. However, voltage source-type pulse power supplies have serious limitations in CCP etching systems. As illustrated in Fig.
1
, a CCP etching system is mainly characterized by a capacitive load impedance. Therefore, when a CCP load is directly connected to the output of voltage source-type pulse power supplies, it is subject to a potential short-circuit current between the two voltage sources. This potential short-circuit current, if not properly avoided, can result in a large ripple current in the plasma load. This large ripple current can lead to the unwanted ringing of the output load voltage which in turn undermines the control accuracy of the electric field within the plasma chamber. Employing an additional inductive filter between the two voltage sources may overcome this problem. However, the use of an additional inductive filter decreases the bandwidth of the control dynamics and may further complicate the regulation of the target output voltage waveform in Fig.
3
.

In addition, it is a big challenge for voltage source-type pulse power supplies to generate the compensating potential (
V
load_slope
) for the plasma etching process shown in Fig.
3
. This compensating potential (
V
load_slope
) is required to properly offset unwanted charging or discharging of the main bias potential due to secondary parasitic circuit elements inside the plasma chamber. The ramping-like shape of this compensating potential (
V
load_slope
) under a fundamental frequency of 100 kHz is hard to generate using the switching-mode voltage source-type pulse power supplies currently available. Therefore, these two major disadvantages of voltage source-type pulse power supplies, short-circuit current and limited compensating potential, put voltage source-type pulse power supplies in an inferior position in terms of application in CCP etching systems. In this paper, a novel current source-type pulse generator is proposed to be a better pulse power supply solution for CCP etching systems.

The proposed current source-type pulse generator (CST-PG) circuit is shown in Fig.
7
. This circuit topology is aimed to meet two important requirements for the power supplies employed in CCP systems: high potential of the electric field and accurate control of the electric field within the plasma chamber. The proposed CST-PG is also intended to overcome the potential problems caused by the voltage source-type circuit topologies employed in CCP systems explained in previous sections. In this paper, the major design goals of the proposed current source-type converter based on three previously mentioned requirements are as follows. The first goal is to keep the source connection rule to reduce the ripple of the load voltage in a CCP system. The second goal is to cope with high voltage generation to easily ignite the plasma within the chamber. The third goal is to implement a suitable topological and control structure to maintain the stability of the plasma load.
Circuit diagram of the proposed current source-type pulse generator

To achieve these three design goals, this paper proposes the CST-PG circuit shown in Fig.
7
. Overall, the proposed CST-PG consists of two current sources:
I
bias
and
I
slope
as shown in Fig.
7
. The main pulse current (
I
bias
), referred to as the
Bias stage
, supports the main bias voltage of the plasma chamber (
V
load_bias
) defined in Fig.
3
. The supplementary charging current (
I
slope
), referred to as the slope stage, determines the compensating slope voltage (
V
load_slope
) to accurately regulate the total output voltage (
V
load_pp
) defined in Fig.
3
. The main bias current (
I
bias
) is bi-directional so that the main bias voltage (
V
load_bias
) can increase (charging
C
Sheath
) and decrease (discharging
C
Sheath
). On the other hand, the supplementary slope current (
I
slope
) is unidirectional, i.e., negative. Thus, the compensating slope voltage is always decreasing (discharging
C
Sheath
) [
12
].

The bias stage is composed of a bias current generator (BCG) and a bias current modulator (BCM). As shown in Figs.
2
and
3
, the duty ratio of the main bias current (
I
bias
), i.e., the duration when the main bias current flows through the plasma load, is less than 2% (a duty of 200 ns in 100 kHz). In other words, during most of the operating cycle, the main bias current is free-wheeling without flowing through the plasma load. Thus, to regulate the amplitude of the main bias current (
I
dc_bias
), the BCG takes the structure of a full-bridge inverter to apply a bi-polar voltage across the output inductor (
L
bias
). In addition, to utilize the fast switching capability of SiC MOSFET switches at a relatively high dc input voltage (
V
dc_bias
) of a few kV, the three-level NPC inverter topology is employed in the BCG. The BCM is designed as a Full-Bridge Current Source Converter (FBCSC) to deliver the DC current (
I
dc_bias
) charged in the DC-link inductor (
L
bias
) to the plasma load with a bi-directional pulse waveform. When the switches
S
BCM1
and
S
BCM4
of the FBCSC turn on, a current of
I
dc_bias
flows to the load. When
S
BCM2
and
S
BCM3
turn on, a current of −
I
dc_bias
flows through the load. In addition, when
S
BCM1
and
S
BCM2
are simultaneously turned on or when
S
BCM3
and S
BCM4
are simultaneously turned on, current does not flow to the load or operate in the free-wheeling mode. By repeating a total of four switching modes, the BCM delivers a bi-directional pulsed current to the load.

The slope stage is divided into the slope current generator (SCG) and the slope current modulator (SCM) illustrated in Fig.
7
. The slope stage supplies the current (
I
slope
) having the negative amplitude of
I
dc_slope
defined in Fig.
3
. This negative current is meant to discharge the load capacitance in such a way that the total peak value of the load bias voltage (
V
load_pp
) is kept within the target range of the plasma load. As noted in Fig.
3
, the duty ratio of the slope current is generally specified to be around 50%, i.e., a duty of 5 μs at 100 kHz, under the steady-state operating condition. This means that the supplementary slope current (
I
slope
) flows through the load impedance during almost half of the switching period. The SCG is designed to regulate and fine-tune the required amplitude of the slope current (
I
dc_slope
) with a relatively high resolution. Due to the particular load bias condition depicted in Fig.
3
, a three-level dc–dc converter topology instead of a full-bridge inverter topology is employed for the SCG unlike the BCG. To exploit the fast switching capability of SiC MOSFETs under the relatively high dc input voltage (
V
dc_slope
) of the dc–dc converter, the three-level topology described in Fig.
7
is selected. The SCM is designed as a half-structure current source converter (HSCSC) to transfer the DC current (
I
dc_slope
) charged in the output inductor (
L
slope
) to the load in a unidirectional pulse waveform. The operation of the SCM is divided into an active switching mode for transferring current to a load, and a zero switching mode for free-wheeling the current. When the switch
S
SCM2
is turned on and
S
SCM1
is turned off, the
I
dc_slope
current is delivered to the load. On the other hand, when the switch
S
SCM1
is turned on and
S
SCM2
is turned off, the
I
dc_slope
current free-wheels through
S
SCM1
instead of flowing to the load. Therefore, according to the switching operation of
S
SCM1
and
S
SCM2
, a unidirectional pulse current having a value of either
I
dc_slope
or 0 flows to the plasma load. The SCM is also designed to avoid any unwanted internal current circulation between the bias stage and the slope stage. The bi-polar characteristic of load voltage necessitates bi-polar voltage blocking capability on the switches of
S
SCM1
and
S
SCM2
, i.e., a combination of a SiC MOSFET and a series diode. As a result, the proposed CST-PG shown in Fig.
7
is aimed to meet various electrical requirements imposed by a typical CCP system. In this paper, a control algorithm and its detailed scheme for the proposed system in Fig.
7
are not treated due to space limitations. Instead, this paper focuses on the topological aspect of the proposed system with respect to the important electrical requirements in a CCP system.

section.data-title: Verification of the proposed CST-PG topology

div.h2: Verification of the proposed CST-PG topology

div.p:
The proposed CST-PG topology is verified through the simulation and experimental results. The results of the verifications are presented in this section. The simulations were performed using the PLECS simulation tool. Experiment has been carried out using the laboratory prototype shown in Fig.
8
. The simulations and experimental parameters are given in Table
1
. These parameters are chosen to confirm the superiority of the proposed topology using the laboratory prototype setup.
Experimental setup of the proposed current source-type pulse generator

figcaption.b: Table 1 Simulation and experiment parameters: current source-type pulse generator

div.p:
The proposed CST-PG circuit is aimed to overcome generic problems such as ringing of the load voltage and inaccurate control of the load voltage faced by a VST-PG in a CCP system as explained in Section III-B. To verify the capability of the proposed CST-PG circuit in solving these problems, VST-PG and CST-PG circuits were compared under the same operating condition of the CCP system as given in Table
1
. Comparative circuits of a VST-PG and a CST-PG are given in Figs.
9
and
10
, respectively. The particular topology of the VST-PG shown in Fig.
9
is typically employed in state-of-the-art technology in the CCP systems of semiconductor industries. In order to compare the ringing of the load voltage and current, only the bias stage is considered without the slope stage as illustrated in Figs.
9
and
10
. The CST-PG circuit shown in Fig.
10
is identical to the bias stage described in Fig.
7
with the block of the BCG represented as a current source for the sake of simplicity. The capacitance (
C
Sheath
) and resistance (
R
Plasma
) of the plasma load are equivalent values obtained from a physical model of a CCP under the conditions of plasma ignition as shown in Fig.
1
. The stray inductance (
L
stray
) represents the sum of stray inductance terms due to the PCB circuit pattern, switching device, and RF cable. The damping resistor (
R
stray
) reflects the damping ratio of the converter hardware system.

Comparative voltage source-type pulse generator including a capacitive coupled plasma load and leakage components (target load voltage
V
load
= 500
V
pp)

Comparative current source-type pulse generator including a capacitive coupled plasma load and leakage components (target load voltage
V
load
= 500
V
pp)

As proposed in this paper, the CST-PG in Fig.
10
has better characteristics in terms of providing a required load voltage than the VST-PG in Fig.
9
. Under ideal operating conditions, the load voltage of the CCP system has a trapezoidal waveform as shown in Fig.
2
. When ringing of the load voltage is introduced into the system due to parasitic elements, the shape of the load voltage deviates from an ideal trapezoidal shape. In this paper, to quantify the degree of deviation from the ideal trapezoidal shape, the
Crest Factor
is utilized as a performance index. The
Crest Factor
is one of the physical quantities for measuring the distortion rate of a periodic waveform. In (2), the Crest factor is defined as the ratio of the peak value against the rms value of the target waveform.
The waveform of an ideal square waveform has a CF value of 1. When the waveform becomes distorted due to ringing, the CF value increases over 1.

Control of the VST-PG in Fig.
9
is done in such a way that the target load voltage of Fig.
2
is generated at the output of the full-bridge side. Simulated waveforms of the load voltage and current in the case of the VST-PG are shown in Figs.
11
and
12
, respectively. As noted in these figures, the load voltage and current are distorted by significant ringing. The CF of the load voltage in Fig.
11
is around 2.44. These distortions of the load voltage and current are mainly due to the existence of the stray components (
L
stray
and
R
stray
) between the full-bridge output of the voltage source converter and the plasma load as shown in Fig.
9
. Even though the VST-PG of the full bridge is well controlled to generate a target voltage waveform like the one in Fig.
2
at the pole side of the full bridge, stray components (
L
stray
and
R
stray
) severely distort the load voltage across the plasma load so that accurate control of the plasma load voltage becomes very challenging. As noted in Fig.
12
, the load current exhibits a large oscillation term. Since the capacitors (
C
Sheath
and
C
dclink
) are connected in parallel with a small impedance from a circuital point of view, a large short-circuit current of 50 A is generated. This large short-circuit current can impose a serious current stress on the overall system. The on-going design trends of higher power and higher fundamental frequency of plasma chambers in the semiconductor industry result in larger parasitic components of
L
stray
and
R
stray
. Therefore, the applicability of the VST-PG in a CCP plasma system becomes further deteriorated.

Simulation waveform of the load voltage of the voltage source-type pulse generator illustrated in Fig.
9

Simulation waveform of the load current of the voltage source-type pulse generator illustrated in Fig.
9

The performance of the CST-PG under the same operating conditions as those of the VST-PG is tested, and its simulation results are presented in Figs.
13
and
14
. It is clearly noted from these figures that CST-PG circuit has less resonance and ringing than the VST-PG. The load voltage is very close to the target waveform of Fig.
2
, and the corresponding CF is around 1.12, i.e.,
V
load_rms
= 250 V and
V
load_peak
= 280 V. The load current has a positive and negative pulse shape that is similar to the ideal CCP current shown in Fig.
14
.

Simulation waveform of the load voltage of the current source-type pulse generator illustrated in Fig.
10

Simulation waveform of the load current of the current source-type pulse generator illustrated in Fig.
10

Experimental verification has been performed on both the VST-PG and the CST-PG under the same operating condition and control strategy as those of the simulations. The experimental results are given in Fig.
15
through Fig.
20
. The measurements of the setup for experimental waveforms are equal to those of simulation results for the sake of a consistent comparison. Figure
15
shows a waveform of the load voltage for the case of the VST-PG. Similar to the obtained simulation waveform, the load voltage has some distortion in terms of ringing due to parasitic elements resulting in a CF value of 2.12, i.e.,
V
load_rms
= 250 V and
V
load_peak
= 530 V. The corresponding load current has a waveform as described in Fig.
16
. It is noted that the peak current value is as high as about 50 A. A waveform of the load voltage in the case of the CST-PG is given in Fig.
17
. When compared to the case of the VST-PG in Fig.
15
, the load voltage is almost free of ringing distortion leading to a CF value of 1.08 (
V
load_rms
= 250 V and
V
load_peak
= 270 V). This value reveals the fact that the CST-PG delivers a nearly ideal pulse voltage to the CCP load. The waveforms of the load voltage and load current in Figs.
17
and
18
are closer to those of Fig.
2
, which confirms the key observations made from the simulation results. Therefore, the experimental results given in Fig.
15
through Fig.
18
verify the superiority of the CST-PG in a CCP system in terms of the lower distortion of the target load voltage in a plasma chamber.

Experimental waveform of the load voltage of the voltage source-type pulse generator illustrated in Fig.
9

Experimental waveform of the load current of the voltage source-type pulse generator illustrated in Fig.
9
(peak current value = 50 A)

Experimental waveform of the load voltage of the current source-type pulse generator illustrated in Fig.
10

Experimental waveform of the load current of the current source-type pulse generator illustrated in Fig.
10
(peak current value = 30 A)

div.h3: Total system verification results of the proposed CST-PG
div.p:
One of the major electrical requirements for the pulse power supplies in CCP systems is the accurate control of target load voltage amplitude. As explained in Section II, due to many parasitic components and intrinsic unstable electrical characteristic of a plasma chamber, the target load voltage shape in Fig.
2
is very difficult to generate. Thus, the function of the compensating bias voltage, the so-called slope bias voltage, is added as shown in Fig.
3
to fine-tune the amplitude of the load voltage. In this paper, the unique structure of the slope current stage block described Fig.
7
is presented to implement this feature of the compensating bias voltage. Simulation and experimental verification of the complete system in Fig.
7
has been performed and the obtained results are given in Fig.
19
through Fig.
22
.

Simulation load voltage waveform of the current source-type pulse generator illustrated in Fig.
7

To control the amplitude of the two current sources (
I
dc_bias
and
I
dc_slope
), the BCG and the SCG use a PWM technique in the corresponding current regulators. Through this operation, the
I
dc_bias
and
I
dc_slope
currents have a constant DC value. The functional blocks of the BCM and the SCM generate the required pulse currents
I
bias
and
I
slope
to the load using
I
dc_bias
and
I
dc_slope
as DC current sources, respectively. The value of
I
bias
having a size of 35 A generates the pulse load voltage.

I
slope
is the current required to make the slope load voltage and it is in the order of 1 A under the rated load conditions. Figure
19
presents a simulation waveform of the load voltage while a waveform of the load current is given in Fig.
20
. The load voltage meets the target shape as described in Fig.
3
and Table
1
(
V
load_pp
= 1.6 kV and
V
load_slope
= 500 V). The load current achieves the target shape as described in Fig.
3
and Table
1
(
I
dc_bias
= 35 A and
I
dc_slope
= 1 A). The load current successfully obtains the target peak value, duration, and current shape. These values are similar to those of the ideal case shown in Fig.
3
.

Simulation load current waveform of the current source-type pulse generator illustrated in Fig.
7

Experiments have been conducted under two different load conditions; (
V
load_bias
= 220 V,
V
load_slope
= 60 V,
V
load_pp
= 280 V) and (
V
load_bias
= 1.1 kV,
V
load_slope
= 500 V,
V
load_pp
= 1.6 kV). Figure
21
shows waveforms of the load voltage and load current under the former load conditions.

Experimental load voltage and current waveforms of the current source-type pulse generator illustrated in Fig.
7
(280 Vpp target)

Waveforms for the latter load conditions are given in Fig.
22
. As shown in Fig.
21
, when the load current of 10 A flows,
V
load
has rising and falling transient values of 220 V and 280 V, respectively. In addition,
V
load
has a falling slope waveform of about 60 V; while, a small slope current of about 0.2 A flows to the load. In Fig.
22
, the target load voltage
V
load_pp
is shown to be 1.6 kV. The amplitudes of
I
bias
and
I
slope
are around 35 A and 1 A, respectively. These controlled pulse currents generate a load voltage in the desired shape shown in Fig.
22
. The pattern of the load waveforms in Figs.
21
and
22
confirms the successful operation of the proposed CST-PG circuit. Therefore, the CST-PG system is a better solution for CCP etching processes than the VST-PG.

Experimental load voltage and current waveforms of the current source-type pulse generator illustrated in Fig.
7
(1600 Vpp target)

Through the simulation and experimental verification results summarized in Fig.
19
through Fig.
22
, the proposed structure of the CST-PG in Fig.
7
is shown to achieve the three design goals explained in Section IV. First, the output load voltage has a very low ringing component (CF < 1.08). This means that the proposed CST-PG is suitable for CCP systems, since this topology effectively complies with the source connection rule. Second, the output voltage is able to achieve the target voltage level (
V
load_pp
= 1.6 kV) even with a lower input voltage level (
V
dc_bias
= 300 V,
V
dc_slope
= 400 V). This higher voltage can contribute to the good plasma load conditions. Third, the slope stage obtains the required slope voltage with a relatively simple circuit structure and switching operation as shown in Fig.
7
. This allows the CST-PG to meet the load requirements of CCP systems.

Conventional pulse power systems based on voltage source-type converter topologies result in electrical problems such as voltage spikes, ringing current, and potential instability in CCP systems. To solve these problems, the CST-PG was proposed in this paper. The proposed converter was designed to meet the requirements of plasma processes with an output voltage of 1.6 kV and an output current of 35A with a fundamental frequency of 100 kHz. Simulation and experimental output waveforms successfully demonstrate the superior performance of the proposed system under the rated conditions. The CST-PG, having two current sources, generates accurately controlled pulse currents
I
bias
and
I
slope
. These output pulse currents have a high fidelity pulse shape as required in CCP systems. Output voltage waveforms of the CST-PG exhibit very low voltage spikes of less than 12% of the fundamental voltage. This value is dramatically less than that of the VST-PG. Hence, the proposed topology provides high reliability via its hardware structure and switching algorithm. Simulation and experimental results confirm the feasibility of the proposed CST-PG for use in CCP processes.

li.p:

(2), 456–463 (2004)

(10), 2844–2845 (2014)

(9), 2527–2535 (2017)

(10), 2857–2864 (2017)
